text: Dems' national lead in House votes just surpassed 9.7 million (now 8.6%). Largest midterm raw vote margin ever; largest % margin since 1986.
author: Redistrict

text: In fact, so far it's not a case of "voter fraud" at all. It's a case of voters being defrauded.
author: Redistrict

text:
This is not a case of "Republican voter fraud." 

This IS a case of a shady operative w/ a checkered past, who has peddled his "services" to D & R candidates in the past, engaging in *absentee ballot fraud* on behalf of a GOP candidate. 

Qs now: how extensive & who knew? #NC09
author: Redistrict

text: The key unresolved #NC09 question in my opinion is: what accounts for the enormous & anomalous share of unreturned absentee ballots in Robeson Co.?
author: Redistrict

text: The CA SoS site is behind. Riverside only has 11k left to count now.
author: Redistrict

text: It’s likely fewer than 37% of Stacey Abrams voters bothered to vote in yesterday’s GA Secretary of State runoff. Had even 40% showed up, Dems would’ve probably won the office.
author: Redistrict

text: Most of those 38k were counted today and Riverside only has 11k left https://www.voteinfo.net
author: Redistrict

text:
I think it was @DKElections that used to describe slow-vote counting election offices as "taking a ganja break." 

As fate would have it the country's biggest stash of remaining uncounted ballots (at least by my estimate) is in Humboldt County, CA.
author: Redistrict

text: Projection: Brad Raffensperger (R) has defeated John Barrow (D) for GA Secretary of State.
author: Redistrict

text: Things you wouldn't guess from Twitter: turns out more Kemp voters than Abrams voters care who GA's next Secretary of State will be. #GASOS
author: Redistrict

text: These kinds of statistically dubious vote swings & aberrations don't occur naturally in the realm of sub-county election results, except for instances of bloc voting by certain religious sects, etc. That's clearly not what was going on here.
author: Redistrict

text:
It's also amazing no one scrutinized the results closely enough the last two razor-thin primaries to cry foul & fully bring to light what was going on (I'm kicking myself, but I wasn't a losing NC campaign). 

If there were a "dumb election criminals" show...Dowless would star.
author: Redistrict

text: The '16 GOP primary, '18 GOP primary & '18 general elections in #NC09 were all decided by fewer than 1,000 votes. In all three cases, Dowless's absentee ballot scheme was hidden in plain sight - in the election results. Amazing anyone thought they could get away with it forever.
author: Redistrict

text:
2016 primary: Dowless works for Todd Johnson (R), who wins Bladen mail-in absentees 221-4-1 (!) over Harris (R) & Pittenger (R).

2018 primary: Dowless works for Harris (R), who wins Bladen mail-in absentees 437-17 (!) over Pittenger (R).

A blatantly obvious absentee mill. #NC09
author: Redistrict

text:
No longer any reasonable doubt as to absentee fraud perpetrated by pro-Harris forces in #NC09 in both primary and general. 

Now questions are: how widespread and who knew?
author: Redistrict

text:
There will only be 3 House Rs from Clinton-won seats in January:

#NY24 John Katko (R)
#PA01 Brian Fitzpatrick (R)
#TX23 Will Hurd (R)

By contrast, there will be 31 House Dems from Trump-won seats.
author: Redistrict

text: Rep. David Valadao (R) is currently posting the third-largest R overperformance vs. Trump's '16 margin in the country, 14.9%. It wasn't enough. #CA21
author: Redistrict

text:
Projection: T.J. Cox (D) has defeated Rep. David Valadao (R) in #CA21, an upset that brings Dems to a *40 seat* gain overall.

Final House breakdown: 235D, 200R.
author: Redistrict

text: Kings Co. reports more votes and Cox (D) *expands* his lead.
author: Redistrict

text:
By itself, Dems winning the House wouldn’t have been enough to ensure Pelosi’s renomination/likely comeback as Speaker.

But the fact a) Dems won House by a large margin and b) only a handful of anti-Pelosi Dem cands (<15) won meant 11/6 was pretty much her best-case scenario.
author: Redistrict

text:
And by caveat, I mean she's ineligible as a non-natural-born citizen. If she were eligible, she might be a nightmare opponent for Trump.

It'd also be fascinating to see how a Blue Dog would play out in a Dem primary. My guess: ideology matters less than most DC types think.
author: Redistrict

text: Another caveat, as many have pointed out: Murphy was born in Vietnam.
author: Redistrict

text: A caveat: this is all under the assumption new members (Spanberger/Sherrill/Slotkin etc.) wouldn’t turn around & run for POTUS just months after getting elected for the first time.
author: Redistrict

text:
In my view, Trump’s worst nightmare Dem challenger in ‘20 would possess the following traits:

1) young & charismatic
2) female
3) aspirational life story
4) natsec background
5) no lengthy pol record

By process of elimination, I’m arriving at #FL07 Rep. Stephanie Murphy (D).
author: Redistrict

text: If Mike Espy (D) had only gotten the 485,131 votes Hillary Clinton had received in 2016, he would've won. That can only mean one thing: Dems need to coax her to move to MS & challenge Hyde-Smith (R) in 2020. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: The last few Hinds precincts were actually from the more R part of the county, and now it's 100% reported. Mostly R precincts outstanding. Hyde-Smith (R) may stay barely above 54% after all. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Incredible: we're now up to 80 districts where 2018 raw House votes cast are at least 90% of 2016 prez votes cast (and still a few ballots left to count).
author: Redistrict

text:
Even in Mississippi, the suburbs are changing: in 2008, Obama took 31% in DeSoto Co. (Memphis burbs) & 42% in Madison Co. (Jackson burbs). 

Tonight, Espy took 41% in DeSoto & 46% in Madison.
author: Redistrict

text: In 2016, Hillary Clinton (D) got 485,131 votes in Mississippi & lost by 18%. Cindy Hyde-Smith (R) is on track to receive fewer votes & win by ~8%. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Hyde-Smith (R)'s lead is 8.8% and falling. Based on what's out, there's a good chance it lands in the 7-8% range. Unimpressive win. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Impressive for Espy (D), and I might even take the over on 46% at the moment. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: In other news, Dems' national lead in House votes just crept up to 8.2% (9.15 million votes), the largest % margin in a midterm since 1986. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1WxDaxD5az6kdOjJncmGph37z0BPNhV1fNAH_g7IkpC0/edit#gid=0 …
author: Redistrict

text: There are some still pretending it's not over, but sorry, it's over. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: With lots of Jackson & the Delta still out, I'm fairly confident Espy (D) will finish within single digits (he's down 11.8% now), but we'll see. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: A good reason to approach early returns w/ caution
author: Redistrict

text: The only question now is the final margin. This looks like a mid-to-high single digit Hyde-Smith (R) win at the moment. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Projection: Cindy Hyde-Smith (R) has defeated Mike Espy (D) in the #MSSEN runoff. But she's done so w/ an underwhelming margin for an R in MS.
author: Redistrict

text: Jasper Co. now 100% reporting. Espy (D) needed around 59% there, is getting 56.5%. Consistent w/ a statewide finish around 46-48%. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: We've got our first complete county in the Delta: Coahoma. Espy (D) needed about 79% there, but he only got 75.6%. Seeing a pattern here... #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Actually, MS does have a Whole Foods but it's in the wealthy part of Hinds Co. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: We've got our first complete county: Amite. Hyde-Smith (R) needed to be at around 55% there, and she finished w/ 58.3%. Good news for her. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Hancock Co. on the Gulf Coast is 96% reporting & Espy (D) is at 26.6% there, running about 5% behind his win target. He better hope the last precinct is a good one for him. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: It would be something of a mindf*** for both parties if Dems were to blow #FLSEN by 10k votes, then pick up #MSSEN in a runoff. Still unlikely.
author: Redistrict

text: The ultimate bellwether tonight might be Madison Co., wealthier Jackson burbs + heavily AA city of Canton. Only 17% reporting there so far. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: DeSoto Co. is now 92% reporting & Hyde-Smith (R) is up to 57.9% there, which is a hair above her statewide win target. Likeliest outcome for now is still a narrow Hyde-Smith win. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Hinds Co. starting to pour in for Espy (D). He's at 90.1% there w/ 18% in. Doesn't mean much b/c it's part of the county & to be expected. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Espy (D) at 43.2% in DeSoto Co. w/ 85% of precincts in. That's a really impressive showing for a Dem there, regardless of whether he wins/loses statewide. Still need to see whole county though. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: I'd still rather be Hyde-Smith (R) than Espy (D) based on the balance of very early results, but this is clearly not shaping up to be a blowout. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Almost all of Warren Co. (Vicksburg) reporting & Espy (D) down to 52.9% there. He probably needs to be in the ~57% range there to win statewide. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Pretty remarkable for Espy (D) that this race is in single digits w/ very little of Jackson or the Delta reporting so far. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Two thirds of DeSoto Co. is now reporting and Hyde-Smith (R) up to 55.6% there. She's not far off her win number there (~57%) now. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: This certainly does not look like a Cindy Hyde-Smith (R) blowout so far. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: About 68% of Warren Co. (Vicksburg) is reporting and Espy (D) at 55.3% there. Probably eventually needs to be at ~57% there to win statewide. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Now w/ 56% of DeSoto Co. reporting, Hyde-Smith (R) lead there up to 8.6%. Eventually needs to be up ~15% there. Her numbers still weak but headed in right direction. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Nearly half of DeSoto Co. is in and Hyde-Smith (R) is still only leading by 5.8% there. A weak showing so far there. Plot is thickening in the Memphis burbs... #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: We have partial results from four counties & Espy (D) is exceeding his statewide breakeven numbers in all four. But b/c MS is so racially polarized, it's extremely hazardous to infer who's ahead based on partial counties. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: A quarter of DeSoto's precincts now reporting, Hyde-Smith (R) up by 6% there. She eventually needs to be up by ~15% there. Still too early to read too much into it. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: First six precincts from DeSoto Co. (Memphis burbs) & Hyde-Smith (R) leads there by 1%. Intriguing for Espy (D), but it's a tiny sample of precincts. #MSSEN
author: Redistrict

text: Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers (R)'s #WA05 just became the 2nd district (other is #MTAL) where 2018 House votes have surpassed 2016 prez votes, at 100.1%.
author: Redistrict

text:
Preliminary '18 House votes cast vs. '16 prez levels by district type*:

Entirely vote-by-mail: 93%
R-to-D flips: 87%
>40% college grads: 87%
Trump-won: 85%
All districts: 84%
Clinton-won: 83%
African-American majority: 83%
Latino majority: 80%

*Excludes unopposed races
author: Redistrict

text:
Preliminary highest turnout CDs (based on House votes/adult citizens):

1. #MN03 - 73%
2. #CO02 - 73%
3. #VA10 - 71%
4. #WA07 - 71%
5. #CO04 - 69%
6. #MN05 - 69%
7. #MN02 - 69%
8. #FL04 - 68%
9. #WA01 - 68%
10. #MI11 - 68%
11. #GA06 - 68%
12. #CO06 - 67%
author: Redistrict

text: It's far from final. Will go higher.
author: Redistrict

text:
Also in January, House Dems will represent:

78% of Whole Foods locations (up from 65% today)
27% of Cracker Barrel locations (up from 21% today)

By far, the widest culture gap ever. (h/t @GrantrGregory)
author: Redistrict

text: To be clear, @CookPolitical's final outlook was a Dem gain of 30-40 seats & it'll end up at the very top of that range. But late on Election Night, it looked like Dems were poised for 35-37. Then virtually every uncalled race went Dems' way.
author: Redistrict

text: This story appears to be incorrect. Democrats won about 13 million more votes than Republicans in 2008, far above their 9.1 million margin in 2018.
author: Redistrict

text:
Another way of looking at it: in January, House Dems will represent:

79% of all Asians
72% of all Latinos
66% of all African-Americans
66% of all Clinton voters
60% of all college grads
54% of all House seats
45% of all whites
39% of all Trump voters
20% of America's land area
author: Redistrict

text: These stats are contingent on Dems picking up #CA21, btw. Also, if it weren't for narrow Dem wins in #ME02 & #NM02, Rs would be ceding just *1.7%* of their land area despite losing 16% of their seats.
author: Redistrict

text: The share of Asian voters turned out to be a pretty good indicator of Dem House pickups. Of the 50 GOP-held seats w/ the highest Asian populations, Dems flipped 27 - which accounts for two thirds of Dems' net gain in the House.
author: Redistrict

text:
House Republicans will represent 17% fewer seats in January. But they'll also represent:

37% fewer Asian constituents
28% fewer Latino constituents
22% fewer college grads
22% fewer Clinton voters
13% fewer Trump voters

Bonus fact: they'll give up just *5%* of their land area.
author: Redistrict

text: If Rep. David Valadao (R) loses in #CA21, as is likely, House Rs will have lost 6/10 of their districts w/ the highest Latino populations. They've already lost 17/25 of their districts w/ the highest Asian populations.
author: Redistrict

text: Also in today's update: CA Gov.-elect Gavin Newson (D) has pulled ahead of John Cox (R) in Orange County by 529 votes. https://www.ocvote.com/fileadmin/live/gen2018/results.htm …
author: Redistrict

text:
Breaking: T.J. Cox (D) has pulled ahead of #CA21 Rep. David Valadao (R) by 438 votes. 

Not a done deal yet, but Dems now on track for a *40 seat* House pickup. That was almost unthinkable on Election Night.
author: Redistrict

text: Just crossed 112 million House votes counted & Dems' national lead is up to 8.1%, surpassing their 8.0% edge from the 2006 wave.
author: Redistrict

text: Democrats' national lead in House votes just surpassed 9 million (8.0%). https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1WxDaxD5az6kdOjJncmGph37z0BPNhV1fNAH_g7IkpC0/edit#gid=0 …
author: Redistrict

text: T.J. Cox (D) now has a better than even chance to defeat Rep. David Valadao (R) in #CA21 and give Dems a 40 seat gain.
author: Redistrict

text: If you exclude CA & NY, where there are millions of ballots left to count, Dem candidates are averaging 95% of Clinton's '16 totals.
author: Redistrict

text:
If you'd told me before the election that Rs would win an average of 83% of Trump's '16 votes in contested House races, I would've told you they were probably on track to keep their majority.

But Dems are averaging 93% of Clinton's totals & are on track for a 40-seat rout.
author: Redistrict

text: Tbh, if Rs drew a new safe Dem district in Austin to make surrounding R districts safer, that's a trade a lot of Austin Dems would take.
author: Redistrict

text: It's really unusual to see almost all the post-election breaks go against one party, but...House Republicans can't seem to catch a break.
author: Redistrict

text: Not that long ago...Jim Costa (D)'s district used to go down to Bakersfield as recently as 2012.
author: Redistrict

text: At the rate late-counted ballots have broken, #CA21 Rep. David Valadao (R) isn’t just in “jeopardy,” he’s probably the underdog. That means the likeliest House outcome at the moment is a Dem gain of *40 seats.*
author: Redistrict

text: Except...it’s not at all “final.” Could we’ll be +40 if #CA21 ballots stay on current trajectory.
author: Redistrict

text: At this rate Rs will have no choice but to draw a new safe Dem Austin vote sink when TX gains seats in 2022, much as Rs did in Columbus, OH in 2012.
author: Redistrict

text:
There are 233 congressional districts w/ a Whole Foods Market (h/t @GrantrGregory), nearly the same number Dems will control in 2019.

Dems will control 67% of those 233 districts come January, up from 55% today.
author: Redistrict

text: Fact: of the 42 House seats Dems have flipped from GOP control so far, exactly two thirds - 67% - contain a Whole Foods Market. None of the three seats Rs flipped from Dem control have one.
author: Redistrict

text: Actually #UT04 is the *only* Utah district without a Whole Foods, but it's surrounded on all sides by them and may have the largest share of shoppers.
author: Redistrict

text: Dems' national lead in raw House votes - now 8.8 million - just broke the record for largest for either party in the history of midterm elections (previous record was 8.7 million set by Dems in 1974).
author: Redistrict

text: Love’s defeat also ensures that Rs will lose 43% of their women in the House, from 23 to just 13. 90% of House Rs will be white men.
author: Redistrict

text:
Rep. Mia Love (R)’s defeat to Ben McAdams (D) in #UT04 gets Dems to +39, w/ the possibility of +40 in #CA21 (I still think Rs will hold #GA07 & #NY27).

The past two weeks have almost gone worse for House Republicans than Election Night itself.
author: Redistrict

text:
The more votes are counted, the more stunning the beatdowns for Rs in Whole Foods burbs:

#IL06: Rep. Peter Roskam (R) now down 22k votes (-7%)
#KS03: Rep. Kevin Yoder (R) now down 30k votes (-10%)
#NJ11: Mikie Sherrill (D) now up 47k votes (+15%)

These Rs never had a chance.
author: Redistrict

text:
Dems' fundraising dominance in 2018 wasn't just the result of anger at an unpopular GOP president in a midterm; it was as much the result of wealthy voters' relatively recent abandonment of GOP/migration to Dems.

This isn't a problem that's going away for GOP anytime soon.
author: Redistrict

text: Without much fanfare, #NE02 Rep. Don Bacon (R)'s lead has narrowed to under 5k votes (2.0%) & #KS02 Rep.-elect Steve Watkins (R)'s lead has narrowed to under 2k votes (0.7%). Tantalizingly close but no cigar for Dems. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1WxDaxD5az6kdOjJncmGph37z0BPNhV1fNAH_g7IkpC0/edit#gid=0 …
author: Redistrict

text: Just crossed 111.1 million votes tallied in U.S. House races. Dems' national lead is up to 8.64 million votes (7.8%) w/ millions more left to count. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1WxDaxD5az6kdOjJncmGph37z0BPNhV1fNAH_g7IkpC0/edit#gid=0 …
author: Redistrict

text: With another Tulare Co. batch, Rep. David Valadao (R)'s lead is back up to 968 votes. But will it be enough to withstand what's left in Fresno & Kern? Too close to call. #CA21
author: Redistrict

text: This is a really ominous batch for #CA21 Rep. David Valadao (R). There are still plenty of votes left in Kern & Fresno for T.J. Cox (D) to make up the gap & get House Dems to a 40 (!) seat gain.
author: Redistrict

text: So there were fewer Salt Lake Co. provisionals counted than some originally predicted - around 8,100. But McAdams (D) won them 5,176 to 2,921 - a much better-than-expected margin for him. Now, it's extremely hard to see how Rep. Mia Love (R) overcomes that deficit. #UT04
author: Redistrict

text: We put ourselves & our predictions out there and try to interpret the data the best we can. Occasionally the result surprises us & that’s what keeps our job interesting.
author: Redistrict

text: The last time Mitt Romney was on the ballot in 2012, Mia Love (R) lost #UT04 by 768 votes. This time, she’s trailing by 739. Wow.
author: Redistrict

text: Breaking: Ben McAdams (D) takes the lead over Rep. Mia Love (R) by 739 votes in #UT04 (and my apologies to @RobertGehrke!).
author: Redistrict

text: Right now, the Utah Co. portion of #UT04 is at 90.2% of its 2016 ballots cast and the Salt Lake Co. portion is at 95.9%, so I'd be surprised if there are 9k SLC/#UT04 ballots left to count as @RobertGehrke estimates. We'll see soon enough.
author: Redistrict

text: Important point: the 16 signatories aren't enough to cost Pelosi the speaker's gavel by themselves, since McAdams (D) would be Dems' 234th seat.
author: Redistrict

text: My only hesitation here is that there’s no guarantee #UT04 houses a proportional share of Salt Lake Co.’s remaining ballots. In fact, most of the urban/Dem-leaning/pro-marijuana areas of Salt Lake Co. are in other CDs. Still think McAdams (D) needs a little luck here.
author: Redistrict

text:
At least 9 Dems disavowed Pelosi on trail/called for "new leadership" & *haven't* signed this letter:

#CA39 Gil Cisneros
#CO06 Jason Crow
#CT05 Jahana Hayes
#ME02 Jared Golden
#MI08 Elissa Slotkin
#MI11 Haley Stevens
#NJ03 Andy Kim
#NJ11 Mikie Sherrill
#VA07 Abigail Spanberger
author: Redistrict

text: The streak remains alive: since 1992, in situations when a president's party has attempted to defend an open House seat the president failed to carry two years earlier, that party has gone *zero* for 31 trying to defend the seat (including 8 GOP losses this year).
author: Redistrict

text: Projection: Gil Cisneros (D) has defeated Young Kim (R) in #CA39. And with that, the final panel of the Orange Curtain has collapsed into a blue sea.
author: Redistrict

text: If you were to impute results for uncontested races based on the vote patterns in other seats, it might cost Dems ~1% of this lead. Keep in mind, four FL races where Dems faced no opposition *hurt* Dems' totals b/c no votes were tallied at all there.
author: Redistrict

text: Dems' national lead in House votes now up to 7.7% (was 5.3% the day after the election). It could conceivably hit 9% when all votes are tallied.
author: Redistrict

text:
Median age of House Dems' freshman class: 45
Median age of House Dems' top three leaders: 78
author: Redistrict

text: Remarkable: now at 66 districts out of 435 where raw votes cast for House in 2018 are at least *90%* of 2016 prez votes (and still millions more left to count). Montana still leads the way at 101.5%. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1WxDaxD5az6kdOjJncmGph37z0BPNhV1fNAH_g7IkpC0/edit#gid=0 …
author: Redistrict

text: Not odd at all. Absentees tend to skew towards college-educated voters, who are more Dem. The pattern's consistent across the board.
author: Redistrict

text: Erie and Livingston counties still haven't reported their absentee & affidavit votes (likely around 8k outstanding). If those votes follow patterns in other counties, McMurray (D) would net around 1,300 votes in Erie & 200 in Livingston. That'd leave Collins w/ about a 1k margin.
author: Redistrict

text: One AP "uncalled" race we haven't talked a ton about here is #NY27, where indicted Rep. Chris Collins (R) leads Nate McMurray (D) by 2,560 votes. It still looks fairly safe for Collins, but that lead could get cut in half...
author: Redistrict

text: BREAKING: As expected, #UT04 GOP Rep. Mia Love (R) has pulled into the lead over Ben McAdams (D) by 419 votes. Hard to see how she relinquishes it now.
author: Redistrict

text: Democrats' national lead in U.S. House races just surpassed 8 million votes (now 7.3%). https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1WxDaxD5az6kdOjJncmGph37z0BPNhV1fNAH_g7IkpC0/edit#gid=0 …
author: Redistrict

text: By same logic, Nancy Pelosi was the "architect" of Democrats' biggest loss of House seats since before WWII.
author: Redistrict

text: Projection: Gov. Rick Scott (R) has defeated Sen. Bill Nelson (D) in #FLSEN. GOP pickup (possible Dem own-goal).
author: Redistrict

text:
It’s staggering to consider how much the OC has changed since Loretta Sanchez (D) upset Rep. Bob Dornan (R) by a razor-thin margin in 1996. 

But some things haven’t changed: Dornan blamed his loss on voter fraud (this time, there’s no evidence):
author: Redistrict

text: New: in #CA39, Gil Cisneros (D) has *taken the lead* over Young Kim (R), by 941 votes. He's on track to complete Dems' wipeout of GOP in Orange County.
author: Redistrict

text: For Ben McAdams (D), this is a case where adding to your lead isn't good news, b/c it wasn't by enough. #UT04 Rep. Mia Love (R) still a favorite to take lead when Utah Co. fully reports.
author: Redistrict

text: There's just one problem w/ the "House Dems excelled by winning most of the close races" narrative: of the 89 House races where the margin is currently less than 10%, Rs are winning 46, Dems are winning 39 and 4 are uncalled.
author: Redistrict

text: Last year, in a surprise to many CA observers, all seven House Rs from Clinton-won districts voted for the GOP’s healthcare bill. Depending on #CA21, it’s possible all seven seats could be totally wiped out.
author: Redistrict

text: In 2016, Clinton carried 46 of CA’s 53 districts & Trump carried 7. There’s still a chance Dems could wipe out all 7 Rs in Clinton districts without picking up a single Trump seat.
author: Redistrict

text: Trivia: if it weren't for narrow Dem victories in #ME02 & #NM02, Dems would've won just 1% more of America's land area despite increasing their share of all 435 House seats by 8% as a result of the 2018 midterms.
author: Redistrict

text: At the time, the @BrennanCenter's findings were picked up by the @AP & retweeted widely. But their numbers were never based in reality & should serve as a cautionary tale for news organizations going forward.
author: Redistrict

text: Of course. But Dems also won far more seats than their share of votes in states like CA, CT, IL, IA, MD, MA, NJ, NM, NY, OR & WA. In the end, Dems won ~54% of votes and - very likely - 54% of seats.
author: Redistrict

text:
In March, the @BrennanCenter put out a wildly wrong, outrage-provoking projection that an 8% Dem vote margin would produce only a 15 seat gain, leaving them well short of a majority. 

Actual result: Dems are on track to win ~8% more votes than House Rs & pick up ~38-39 seats.
author: Redistrict

text:
Biggest surprise to me so far: how much House Dems were able to overcome their geographic disadvantage w/ $$, R open seats, PA remap, etc.

In 2012/14/16, Dems won a 4-5% smaller share of seats than major party votes. In 2018, they're on track for 54% of votes *and* seats.
author: Redistrict

text: And, #ME02 Rep.-elect Jared Golden (D) used to work for her.
author: Redistrict

text: Rep. Bruce Poliquin (R) becomes the first incumbent to lose reelection in #ME02 since 1916. Meanwhile, Jared Golden (D) becomes the 11th Dem who has said he/she won't back Pelosi to capture a House seat this year.
author: Redistrict

text:
Republicans admitted before the election they had a big "ranked choice problem" in #ME02, and they were right. 

Final tabulation: Jared Golden (D) has defeated Rep. Bruce Poliquin (R) 139,231 to 136,326 for another Dem pickup.
author: Redistrict

text: Excuse me, meant Fresno & *Kern,* not just Kings. #CA21
author: Redistrict

text: This tiny addition of 250 votes from Tulare Co. seems insignificant, but if T.J. Cox (D) is winning 72% of provisionals in a county Rep. David Valadao (R) *won,* that's terrible news for Valadao. Imagine what's to come in Fresno & Kings. #CA21
author: Redistrict

text: We had some misses this cycle, to be sure, but I think this story aged pretty well. Good candidates are as important as good maps (and sometimes, self-funders aren't worth the $$ they bring to the table). #PA01
author: Redistrict

text: It's now virtually certain that Orange County, CA will be represented by zero Republicans in Congress in 2019. And, all of NJ will have only one.
author: Redistrict

text:
Except, @RobertGehrke's estimate of outstanding #UT04 ballots doesn't make sense. It would put Salt Lake Co. at 99% of '16 turnout & Utah Co. at just 83%. 

That's preposterous, esp. b/c Utah Co. is the fastest-growing portion of #UT04. "Toss Up" is being generous to McAdams (D).
author: Redistrict

text: In the end, Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R)'s #CA48 reelection bid didn't even come that close. His deficit vs. Harley Rouda (D) is now 5.4% and growing.
author: Redistrict

text: Projection: Katie Porter (D) has defeated Rep. Mimi Walters (R) in #CA45.
author: Redistrict

text: Breaking: Orange Co. update drops Young Kim (R)'s lead over Gil Cisneros (D) from 590 votes to just *122* votes. It's only a matter of time until Cisneros overtakes her.
author: Redistrict

text: FWIW, if each of these races breaks down as forecast above, Dems would score a net gain of 38 seats.
author: Redistrict

text:
Ok, guess I'll join in. At the moment, here's how I'd rate each uncalled House race:

#CA21: David Valadao (R) - Lean R
#CA39: OPEN (R) - Likely D
#CA45: Mimi Walters (R) - Likely D
#GA07: Rob Woodall (R) - Likely R
#ME02: Bruce Poliquin (R) - Lean D
#UT04: Mia Love (R) - Lean R
author: Redistrict

text: New in #CA21: a Kings Co. update extends Rep. David Valadao (R)'s lead by 206 votes from 1,884 to 2,090. But that's to be expected. Still going down to wire.
author: Redistrict

text: Breaking: in #CA39, Young Kim (R)'s lead over Gil Cisneros (D) drops from 711 to 590 w/ a San Bernardino update. Cisneros could well take the lead today.
author: Redistrict

text: BREAKING: #UT04 Rep. Mia Love (R) narrowly wins latest batch of votes from Salt Lake Co., narrowing Ben McAdams (D)'s lead form 1,227 to 873. This makes her the favorite to prevail, once more Utah Co. votes are counted.
author: Redistrict

text: New in #CA22: Rep. Devin Nunes (R)'s lead tightens from 10.2% to 8.0% w/ more Fresno ballots counted. text: Not really. @RobertGehrke's article estimates there are 34k ballots left in Salt Lake & 5k ballots left in Utah. But you just said there are probably 10k ballots left in Utah, which would make more sense...and it would also put Love in great position.
author: Redistrict

text: Either way, based on the current differential in counted votes between Salt Lake Co. & Utah Co., I'd characterize #UT04 as closer to a Toss Up than "Lean McAdams."
author: Redistrict

text:
Why not? The Utah Co. part of #UT04 isn't *that* demographically dissimilar from parts of southern Salt Lake Co., and it's also the fastest-growing part of the CD.

It's *possible* a higher share of what's out in Utah Co. is in #UT04 or a lower share of SLC's remaining votes are.
author: Redistrict

text: Fwiw, I have a hard time buying the @sltrib's estimate that there are 34k #UT04 ballots left in Salt Lake Co. & just 5k in Utah Co. That would put Salt Lake Co. turnout at around ~99% of 2016 turnout & Utah Co. turnout at just ~84%. Doesn't make sense.

text: One of my favorite parts of 2018: nerding out about the House has been all the rage. Sad it's ending, but today I thought it'd be fun to compare final predictions w/ those of 4 friends. May the best prognosticator win! (only races where we disagreed shown):
author: Redistrict

text:
If there's a long shot race in our Solid R column that really intrigues me, it's #TX25, which includes UT Austin campus & where Julie Oliver (D) just went up on TV vs. Rep. Roger Williams (R) over the weekend. 

R+11 CD but w/ Beto on the ballot, curious the margin there.
author: Redistrict

text:
Trump's cultural appeals have energized his base more than tax cuts did in special elections & it's contributing to today's sky-high turnout.

But they could also generate backlash & surprises in "melting pot" burbs like Gwinnett, GA; Fort Bend, TX; Dallas, TX etc. Keep eye out.
author: Redistrict

text: If you're looking for surprises/Dem upsets tonight, I'd look at the few remaining Republicans in districts that are (or recently have become) majority non-white. Suburbs of Atlanta, Miami, Houston, etc.
author: Redistrict

text:
Bottom line: if every Lean/Likely/Solid race breaks as expected, Rs would need to win 23 of 30 @CookPolitical Toss Ups (77%) to keep their House majority. 

Not impossible, but very difficult.

author: Redistrict

text: If the 30 Toss Ups were to break evenly between the parties, Dems would score a net gain of exactly 30 seats. However, "wave" parties typically win solid majorities of Toss Ups & even a few Lean/Likely races.
author: Redistrict

text:
Here's how to track the House: 

If every Lean/Likely/Solid race were to break as expected, Dems would need to win just 8 of 30 Toss Ups (27%) to win the majority. 

By contrast, Republicans would need to win 23 of 30 Toss Ups (77%) to keep theirs. Not impossible, but difficult.
author: Redistrict

text: NEW: there are 435 House races. Need to keep track of what's in play on Election Night? Here's a free PDF of @CookPolitical's *final* 2018 House Ratings: https://adobeindd.com/view/publications/70ce2106-5967-41ae-9dd7-61579de7232f/1/publication-web-resources/pdf/House_Race_Ratings.pdf …
author: Redistrict

text: In some ways, it feels a little like the lead-up to 2012, when the cable TV chatter was obsessed w/ national polls showing Romney closing in on Obama, but in reality Obama retained important advantages in key Electoral College battlegrounds.
author: Redistrict

text:
This morning's new NBC/WSJ *national* numbers are really positive for Rs: they suggest Dems' & college+ voters' enthusiasm edge is virtually gone.

But we just haven't seen much movement towards Rs in *battleground* House races, where Dems continue to dominate spending/airwaves.
author: Redistrict

text: It's fascinating to watch the disconnect between cable news, where there's a lot of freaking out about whether the "blue wave" is a thing of the past, vs. district-level polls and spending, which clearly continue to favor Dems.
author: Redistrict

text: Now that it's a wrap, let me say: congrats to @Nate_Cohn, @UpshotNYT & @SienaResearch on a groundbreaking project that's (hopefully) shed more light on House races than there's ever been. Thank you...really.
author: Redistrict

text: Regarding #GA06, it's possible Stacey Abrams (D) & Lucy McBath (D) are better-suited to turning out the Dem base than Jon Ossoff (D) & $30 million ever were. We'll see.
author: Redistrict

text: WY bother polling here when there are so many other races in need?
author: Redistrict

text: Third to last place is Montgomery (82%), the most Republican large county. This doesn't at all make clear who's going to win, but it does suggest left-leaning white enthusiasm is running ahead of Republican & Hispanic enthusiasm relative to '16.
author: Redistrict

text:
TX early vote running *almost* at '16 pace, which is pretty incredible. Top counties so far: Dallas (93% of '16 pace), Travis (91%) - two of the biggest bastions of Dem-trending whites.

At the bottom: Hidalgo (77%), Cameron (81%), the two largest 80%+ Hispanic counties.
author: Redistrict

text:
R incumbents have long had massive problems in elite, upscale Clinton-won burbs like #CO06, #IL06, #KS03 #MN03 & #VA10.

The difference now: R problems are worsening in mixed, middle-income burbs Trump won by single digits like #IL14, #IA03, #GA06 #MI08, & #UT04.
author: Redistrict

text: Update: Steve King (R)'s lead has bounced back up to 48%-43% w/ 248 #IA04 respondents. Bouncy & a long way to go, but so far King's own poll - which had him up 52%-34% - looks either outdated, wrong or both.
author: Redistrict

text: From a House control standpoint, however, the worse news for Rs is that two incumbents who were thought to be favored a few weeks ago - #GA06 Rep. Karen Handel (R) and #IL14 Rep. Randy Hultgren (R) - are both sucking wind, trailing their Dem opponents at the moment.
author: Redistrict

text: #IA04: Rep. Steve King (R)'s lead over J.D. Scholten (D) down to 46%-45% nearly halfway thru NYT/Siena poll. Scholten now airing *two minute* ads.
author: Redistrict

text: #IA04 Rep. Steve King (R) finally went up on the airwaves at 1:18pm today, 2.5 weeks after his opponent. The ad looked familiar to me...and yup, it's a recycled ad from his *2014* race. http://mycmag.kantarmediana.com/KMIcmagvidbin2/HOUSE_IA04_KING_GREW_UP_IN_IOWA.html …
author: Redistrict

text: I’d like to publicly acknowledge & thank all the “geniuses” who are “never wrong” for keeping us so well-informed this year
author: Redistrict

text: When I go district-by-district, I keep coming back to a place where the House isn't a coin flip as @SeanTrende suggests it might be, but we're probably not at a midpoint of Dems +38 as @FiveThirtyEight's model suggests either.
author: Redistrict

text: No, which is why I might still consider Young a slight favorite
author: Redistrict

text: Then again, you could make the case Spanberger (D)'s current 51%-39% lead in Chesterfield is coming in "hot." Which is why I generally try to avoid critiquing polls by pointing to small, regional subsamples (failing in this case).
author: Redistrict

text: Try my best not to "unskew," but interesting results so far in #VA07, where Brat (R) currently leads Spanberger (D) 48%-41%, powered by a 52%-39% lead in Henrico (by far the most Dem part of the CD). I'm guessing it'll tighten.
author: Redistrict

text: Wouldn't beat myself up if that happens. We think anything from 20 to 45 is well within realm of possibility, but 30-40 is the most likely outcome as of *today.*
author: Redistrict

text: The fact that many of these "single digit Trump" suburbs - along with Trump-won open seats like #FL15, #NM02 & #VA05 - are now in serious jeopardy is what could push Dem gains into the 30-40 seat range (vs. 25-35 before).
author: Redistrict

text: 3) Finally, middle-class burbs where Trump won by single digits that will decide the majority: places like #IL14 Hultgren, #IA03 Young, #MI08 Bishop, #PA10 Perry, #UT04 Love, #WA03 Herrera Beutler. *This* is the bucket where we've seen Dems make the most progress recently.
author: Redistrict

text: 2) Competitive races in redder, working-class districts that Trump won by double digits in '16, such as #IL12 Bost, #MN08 OPEN, #NY22 Tenney, #WV03 OPEN, etc. Overall, things have slightly improved in "Trump zones" for Rs, w/ notable exceptions in districts like #KS02 & #ME02.
author: Redistrict

text: 1) Vulnerable Rs in upscale, suburban, Clinton-won "Whole Foods" districts like #VA10 Comstock, #KS03 Yoder, #CO06 Coffman, #MN03 Paulsen, #CA45 Walters, #NJ07 Lance, etc. These Rs are mostly trailing & their numbers haven't gotten any better recently.
author: Redistrict

text: Why the slight shift? Let me try to explain what we've observed move post-Labor Day. There are basically 3 large buckets of House races we're watching...
author: Redistrict

text: One of the remaining '18 mysteries: what % does #NY14 Rep. Joe Crowley (D) get as the WEP/WF nominee vs. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D) on Tuesday?
author: Redistrict

text: Almost like King just realized there was an election... #IA04
author: Redistrict

text: New: based on the past week’s evidence, we’re revising our House outlook to a Dem gain of 30-40 seats (was 25-35 last month) at @CookPolitical. This could change again before Tuesday.
author: Redistrict

text: I'm skeptical. @SusquehannaPR's Trump approval %s in both #PA11 & #PA16 are both 12% below his share of the vote in each CD, which to me suggests a sample that's too "hot" for Dems.
author: Redistrict

text:
This will be a rare look at whether an unanswered ad campaign can move the needle in an R+11 seat.

J.D. Scholten (D) is framing King as an AWOL from #IA04 (vs. calling him a racist/neo-Nazi). 

Meanwhile, King isn’t really running a campaign.
author: Redistrict

text: Trend line not good for the GOP in my home district, #NJ07. If Rs were to hold the majority, a few moderates like Rep. Leonard Lance (R) would need to hang on.
author: Redistrict

text: If paying for family members' salaries over ads costs Steve King #IA04...we're probably not talking House control....we're talking Dems going like +50 seats.

text: New at @CookPolitical: our one-week-out House ratings. Download a presentation-ready PDF here: https://adobeindd.com/view/publications/16896a1e-26eb-40f7-b396-39b692c30689/1/publication-web-resources/pdf/House_Race_Ratings.pdf …
author: Redistrict

text: No doubt it's a great internal number for King - and reinforces that he's still the clear fave in #IA04 - but it's also a week older than the @ChangePolls survey & also may help explain why King hasn't aired any ads/taken the race seriously.
author: Redistrict

text: To be clear, Rohrabacher's still in a lot of trouble. It's just amazing he's still in the game given the other three OC R's are women w/ more conventional GOP appeal & are running more robust campaigns.
author: Redistrict

text: Remarkable: of the four R-held Clinton CDs in Orange County, the Republican w/ the best chance of winning is probably #CA48 Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R).
author: Redistrict

text: King's only response? An Oct. 22-24 @WPAIntel (R) poll showing him leading 52%-34%.
author: Redistrict

text: This is a *very* different situation than '12 or '14, when King ran was less of a pariah, ran a robust TV campaign & won #IA04 convincingly. He's now completely dark on TV & his campaign's YouTube channel hasn't been updated in 4 years. https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2ysoeWT3QbOmdRpjxfAyiQ …
author: Redistrict

text: That's a big reason why he's still the underdog in #IA04.
author: Redistrict

text: King is virtually broke (had $176k on hand in mid-Oct. and badly outraised by Scholten) & with a week left, it's unclear who's going to bail him out. The only thing he's got going for him now is #IA04's 27% Trump margin & R+11 PVI.
author: Redistrict

text:
So far in #IA04, J.D. Scholten (D) has spent over $1.4 million & has been on air *unanswered* for 2 weeks. An Evan McMullin-backed PAC has joined w/ $300k calling King (R) "Klan & Neo-Nazi approved."

King's spent $782k, but mostly on fundraising/family salaries. No ads yet (!).
author: Redistrict

text: Presented without comment. #CA16

text:
There are a few reasons to doubt they'll break in the same pattern as '06/'10:

1) R voters are far more engaged in '18 than they were in '06 or Dems were in '10.
2) Far more polling this year, giving us more opportunities to "diagnose" R problems. Still, a few surprises likely.
author: Redistrict

text:
I went back thru @CookPolitical's final ratings for 2006 & 2010 last night. Found the "wave" party averaged 100% of their own Lean/Likely/Solids, 57% of Toss Ups, 19% of opposite Leans, 9% of Likelys & 0% of Solids.

In 2018, that same pattern would net Dems +39.8 seats. But...
author: Redistrict

text: This AJC article offers a much more coherent & detailed case for how GA's aggressive removal of inactive voters differs from other states', although some important context is missing from the lede.
author: Redistrict

text: It’s routine to remove inactive voters in these states too, even if they haven’t moved.
author: Redistrict

text: Do GA & other states have disgraceful histories of voting discrimination? Absolutely. But this article & others should offer more evidence & context of how the 340k purge was materially different from the routine purges of millions of inactive voters in CA, MD, NY, etc.
author: Redistrict

text:
This @RollingStone article asserts Kemp "incorrectly" and "improperly" removed 340k inactive voters, then much later notes that "this practice is now legal" thanks to SCOTUS. 

More evidence needed on whether a) he broke the law or b) the law is broken.
author: Redistrict

text:

author: Redistrict

text:
To be clear, the purpose of this 44/-4 stat has never a prediction; it’s been to illustrate that the House & Sen might as well be Mars & Venus this year.

The point: if Dems were to gain, say, 33 House seats and lose 3 Senate seats, those outcomes could be entirely consistent.
author: Redistrict

text: Tbh, when I wrote this back in April, I didn't think we'd be as close to this degree of House/Sen divergence as we are now.
author: Redistrict

text:
R improvement has been most pronounced in the Senate, but Rs have also seen uptick in plenty of CDs where Trump was over 50% in ‘16: #AR02, #IL12, #MN08, #NY22, #OH01, #TX31, #WV03.

Are there exceptions? Sure. But overall, I do think this *probably* lowers Dems’ ceiling a bit.
author: Redistrict

text:
To extent there's been movement since Labor Day, we've *mostly* seen House/Sen races polarize in the direction of partisan fundamentals, which is...what usually happens.

That *probably* limits how deeply Dems can drive into Trump country, but still a high degree of uncertainty.
author: Redistrict

text: Right, I'm saying it's the opposite of the rural/anti-Obama CDs Dems were defending/losing in '10.

text:

At some point, you fall off that tightrope.
author: Redistrict

text: Interesting thing in #NY23 is that Reed (R) has succeeded several times by running against part of *his own* district - calling his opponents "liberal Ithaca extremists" - several times. Same dynamic working in his favor yet again this time.

Even so, late surge in young/nonwhite engagement keeps Dems poised for big House/Gov gains. 

Folks, this is gonna be a very high turnout midterm.

text:

2) Rs have ticked up in areas Trump surged in '16, but not in the bulk of suburban CDs that will decide House
3) 23+ seats (still consensus forecast) *is* a wave

author: Redistrict

text: There are a ton of valid concerns about the restrictive impact of new voting laws & voters improperly removed from rolls, but there's also a lot of outrage-stoking and sloppy journalism in this realm that are counterproductive to fixing real problems.
author: Redistrict

text:
Too many stories ascribing sinister motives to "voter purges" need more:

1) Prominent context that removing inactive voters from rolls is a necessary & standard practice in every state w/ registration
2) Hard evidence that election admins disregarded laws/procedures in doing so.
author: Redistrict

text:
Of the 46 R seats we rate as most vulnerable (Toss Up or worse), *33* are predominantly suburban. Only a handful more rural like #IA01 or #ME02.

So yes, Dems are holding their own in Obama/Trump districts. But any House takeover is very likely to be driven by anti-Trump suburbs.
author: Redistrict

text: Yes, they’re performing about as well in both & agree w/ you on mean reversion. But b/c Dems already hold 14/28 Obama-Trump seats and *zero* Romney-Clintons, it’s accurate to say Dem *gains* are likely to be concentrated in burbs where Trump is weak.

text: Oh believe me, the question of which Solid R seats should be in our Likely R column (and there are like 20 I could make a case for) is what keeps me up at night. I’m sure a few will end up being close & it kills me not to know which ones. Partly what makes this so much fun.
author: Redistrict

text: I certainly see it as a decent proxy for those things too. But sometimes $ can reflect enthusiasm from outside the CD (e.g. MJ Hegar, Andrew Janz). And sometimes candidate quality doesn’t end up mattering much. My point is, the tale $$ tells can vary a lot from race to race.
author: Redistrict

text: Also think you’d agree Q3 FEC reports can be an imperfect gauges. For example, I’m not convinced McMurray’s $460k-$6k quarter over Collins suddenly swings the margin +8 for Dems in #NY27, considering Collins could prob write himself a late 7-figure check. https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/election-update-how-the-latest-fundraising-numbers-shifted-our-house-forecasts/ …
author: Redistrict

text: Entirely fair. I’m betting on “too much” and we’ll see which way it goes. In my experience, the importance of $$ is frequently overstated in House analysis & the role of fundamentals (PVI/partisan lean/turnout dynamics/demographics) undervalued.
author: Redistrict

text: P.S. This is not to downplay the magnitude of Dems’ fundraising success or argue $$ is a bad thing to have. It’s obviously a really, really good thing to have. We just don’t have a lot of recent, consistent examples of *how much* massive $$ disparities actually move races.
author: Redistrict

text:
A lot also depends on *how* these Dems spend their $$ and whether they truly have an airtime edge in the final weeks or already had their chance to be on air unanswered. 

Personally, I might still be in the 75% chance & 30-35 seat range. We’ll see.
author: Redistrict

text: Dem fundraising numbers & cash advantages over R incumbents are without precedent. But there’s no guarantee lots more $$ will move races by a lot, especially in a hyper-partisan era when districts are less elastic than they used to be.
author: Redistrict

text: The 538 House “Classic” forecast now has Dems at 84% to take control & an average gain of 39 seats. I suspect both are slightly too high, b/c the model is reading a bit too much into Dems’ staggering Q3 $$ bonanza.

text:
The only NYT/Siena polls so far that have fundamentally changed my view of a race: #CO06 & #MN03, both in Dems’ direction. 

These CDs have a lot in common and it could be a sign of the bottom simply falling out for Rs in upscale suburban Clinton zones.
author: Redistrict

text:
For example, Davis (D) is up 1% in #KS02, but the fact he’s better-known than Watkins (R) by 17 points says he’s still the underdog, imho.

The fact that Roskam (R) is up 1% in #IL06 despite being better-known than Casten (D) by 27 points should tell you he’s in *deep* trouble.
author: Redistrict

text:
A district’s partisan lean is likely to tell you a lot about the nature of the undecideds, a too-often overlooked group in 2016. 

And, candidates’ images are valuable indicators of their upside vs. a poll. In many races, candidates’ leads are really temporary name ID advantages.
author: Redistrict

text:
Knowing who’s truly “ahead” in a poll involves a lot more than reading the top line numbers.

For example, I’d *much* rather be Sean Casten (D), who’s trailing by one in #IL06 (Clinton +7) than Paul Davis (D), who leads by one in #KS02 (Trump +18).

text: If that red-state Dem dam breaks - and it *could* in November - we could be headed for a Senate that's largely accountable to a white, rural, pro-Trump minority of the country. At some point, the coastal/urban majority could run out of patience - threatening democratic stability.
author: Redistrict

text: For all the gerrymandering in the House, it's actually the Senate that's vastly more unrepresentative. The fact it's remotely close owes to 11 red-state Dem senators - almost entirely up in 2018 - who have hung on thanks to an extraordinary combination of skill & luck.
author: Redistrict

text: And, 60% of the Senate now represents just 24% of the country’s population. This penalty for Dems is on full display in 2018:
author: Redistrict

text: A long-term problem for Democrats: a majority of the Senate now represents 18% of the country’s population.
author: Redistrict

text:
A lot of Dems tend to forget: this year's median competitive Senate seat gave Trump 56% in '16 & is 80% white. 

Median competitive House seat: 49% Trump, 74% white.

U.S. as a whole: 46% Trump, 62% white.

https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/20/opinion/midterms-democrats-republicans-blue-wave.html?smid=tw-nytopinion&smtyp=cur …
author: Redistrict

text: We've never seen this little overlap: of the 64 most competitive House races, just 14 are in states with competitive Senate races. This suburban vs. rural dynamic could have long-lasting consequences. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/20/opinion/midterms-democrats-republicans-blue-wave.html?smid=tw-nytopinion&smtyp=cur …
author: Redistrict

text: Mars vs. Venus: in 2018, the median competitive Senate seat is 7% more pro-Trump, 4x less dense, 5% less college-educated & 7% whiter than the median competitive House seat. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/20/opinion/midterms-democrats-republicans-blue-wave.html?smid=tw-nytopinion&smtyp=cur …
author: Redistrict

text: Fact: if every state/district's result in November were an 8% uniform swing in Dems' favor from the '16 prez result, Dems would simultaneously gain 44 House seats (almost twice the +23 they need), but *lose* 4 Senate seats. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/20/opinion/midterms-democrats-republicans-blue-wave.html?smid=tw-nytopinion&smtyp=cur …

text: I totally sympathize with you. Alas, the PVI metric predates my time at the Cook Political Report.
author: Redistrict

text: This is slightly different from @FiveThirtyEight's also-useful "partisan lean," which averages parties' past *margins.* Hence why our R+7 might be their R+14.
author: Redistrict

text:
To clarify @CookPolitical PVI: it measures how much more D/R each district votes relative to the nation in the last 2 prez elections. 

So in a neutral political enviro, an R in an R+7 seat might expect 57% of the two-party vote. A Dem in a D+4 district might expect 54%, etc.
author: Redistrict

text: PVI measures how much more D/R the district votes for prez than the nation as a whole. 538 measures the margin b/t Ds/Rs, so effectively double.
author: Redistrict

text:
*checks 2017 gubernatorial results in #VA10* 

Ralph Northam (D) 55.6%
Ed Gillespie (R) 43.3%
author: Redistrict

text: Of the 62 seats we rate as "competitive" (Lean or Toss Up), Dems now only need to win 25 (40%) to win the majority. Republicans need to win 38/62 (61%).
author: Redistrict

text: If Dems hold all of their own seats (except #PA14) & win all 10 R seats rated Lean/Likely Dem, they'd need to win 14 more for a majority. There are 25 R seats in Toss Up & 26 more in Lean R.
author: Redistrict

text: Latest @CookPolitical House ratings: 66 at-risk seats (61 R-held, 5 D-held rated Lean or worse). https://www.cookpolitical.com/ratings/house-race-ratings …
author: Redistrict

text: To give you an idea: if Dems were to overperform PVI by 8% in all 435 districts this November (won't happen b/c of R incumbency, etc.), they'd pick up 81 House seats - more than triple the 23 they need.
author: Redistrict

text: Now *final:* Dems overperformed @CookPolitical PVI by an average of 8% in this cycle's 9 House specials where both parties appeared on the final ballot.

text: But it's also why CDs w/ big urban/rural divides are especially dangerous for Rs. For example, high D energy in Portland/Spokane/Seattle burbs & low R energy in rurals is a potentially toxic combo for #WA03 Herrera Beutler (R), #WA05 McMorris Rodgers (R), #WA08 Rossi (R).

text: That's why I'm skeptical when I hear, for example, @SteveSchmidtSES say #OH12 is evidence districts like Rep. Bob Gibbs's #OH07 are "in play." It's an R+12 seat w/ far more rural areas/far fewer anti-Trump suburbs than #OH12 (R+7).

text: Pattern in #ALSEN, #PA18 & #OH12: Dems aren't necessarily making huge % strides in hardcore Trump zones. There, it's more a story of pathetic R turnout, which then allows anti-Trump energy in burbs to put Dems in contention.

text:
When I first got to UVA in '02 & asked @LarrySabato to be my faculty advisor, I told him I couldn't wait to take every politics class. His reply: "No. If you really want to understand politics, take Abnormal Psychology."

That may have been the best advice I ever received. #VA05
author: Redistrict

text: It was astounding how many ppl replied to my tweet about the NYT map/70% of Americans living in "landslide precincts" w/ variants of "time to end this egregious gerrymandering"
author: Redistrict

text: Please get me off of this beat

text: As I was saying, welcome to the most bizarre House race in the country. #VA05
author: Redistrict

text: Team ‘self-sorting is the result of gerrymandering’ might be giving them a run for their $$ tbh
author: Redistrict

text: And which party is living in more of a bubble? Notice that it depends on what threshold you set. At "most neighbors," it's the GOP. At "two thirds," it's Dems.
author: Redistrict

text:
The growth of the "bubbles" is even more dramatic at the extremes: in 2016, 39% of Trump voters & 42% of Clinton voters lived in precincts where more than *two thirds* of their neighbors voted the same way.

In 2012, just 32% of Romney voters & 38% of Obama voters did.
author: Redistrict

text: The numbers from prior years would illustrate this even more drastically, but sadly I don’t have 100% complete data sets before ‘12.
author: Redistrict

text:
By my math: in 2016, 72% of Trump voters & 66% of Clinton voters lived in precincts where most of their neighbors voted the same way.

In 2012, 69% of Romney voters & 65% of Obama voters did. That's how steadily America is sorting into like-minded bubbles.
author: Redistrict

text: Not sure how many people fully appreciate how rapidly, recently & profoundly this neighborhood-level polarization has taken place - in part b/c America has remained so evenly divided overall.
author: Redistrict

text:
It's simple, folks: red neighborhoods are getting redder & blue neighborhoods are getting bluer. In 2016, it accelerated.

This rapid voter self-sorting (not redistricting) explains 83% of the massive decline in swing House seats since 1997 - a key cause of DC dysfunction.
author: Redistrict

text: It doesn't matter which map format you prefer (dot, cartogram, etc.). The essential takeaway - the disappearance of purple America - is the same.
author: Redistrict

text: And no, this rapid geopolarization isn't attributable to gerrymandering (though it's helped make partisan gerrymandering much more effective).
author: Redistrict

text:
Just finished calculating: in 2016, 70% of U.S. voters lived in "landslide precincts" (20%+ margin either way), up from 64% in 2012.

This map shows America literally coming apart.
author: Redistrict

text: Many quant-only models won't tell you that #CA21 Rep. David Valadao (R) is the clear favorite in a D+5 seat, or that Amy McGrath (D) is a strong contender in R+9 #KY06. But they are, b/c there's more to the story than past prez data.

text:
Bottom line: if you really want to track 2018, do yourself a favor and go *beyond* fancy models/big data. Get to know the people running. 

Subscribe to @CookPolitical & @InsideElections. Sign up for @LarrySabato's Crystal Ball. On Election Night, you'll be the wiser for it.

text: Do we have blind spots? Of course. Most of us missed @Ocasio2018, in part b/c of past trends in #NY14 (Cuomo/Clinton) & b/c so much of our focus has been on the 90+ races that will decide House control. But surprises keep politics exciting & make us strive to get better.

text: And to be clear, the GOP's 21% lead in returned ballots in #AZ08 didn't mean Lesko (R) was going to win by 21%. But it meant that turnout was very likely "normal" enough that she would still win, and she did.
author: Redistrict

text:
Early vote data in April's #AZ08 special was pretty meaningful because it was such an overwhelming share of overall votes cast.

That's *not* the case in #OH12, where some are prematurely inferring an enthusiasm edge for Danny O'Connor (D) from absentees cast/requested, etc.

text: And it's not just TX.

text:
To some extent, the focus on the "Blue Wave" has overshadowed an equally important 2018 trend: the slow, steady purge of Trump skeptics from the GOP owing to 1) retirements 2) primary losses 3) Nov. losses.

*except in Utah.

text: UPDATED w/ latest results: so far in '18, female candidates are overperforming by an average of 12.2% in Dem primaries vs. 4.8% in GOP primaries (graphic credit: @CookPolitical intern Jacob Link).
author: Redistrict

text:
Right now, Dems are all kinds of excited about what taking over the House (I'd put odds at ~60%) would mean for governance.

In reality, managing a caucus that could include *both* pro-DSA Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez #NY14 & Trump-voting Richard Ojeda #WV03 sounds...hard.
author: Redistrict

text:
For those insistent that @Ocasio2018's triumph was all about progressivism vs. corporatism (and less about demographic contrast & hustle), here's a reminder of some past Dem primary results in #NY14:

2014: Cuomo (D) 76%, Teachout (D) 24%
2016: Clinton (D) 58%, Sanders (D) 42%
author: Redistrict

text: This 65% on the Dem side is actually down from 71% before the 6/26 primaries. While Ocasio-Cortez dominated the headlines, women had a relatively mediocre night in Dem primaries/runoffs elsewhere.
author: Redistrict

text:
UPDATE: so far in 2018 Dem House primaries featuring at least one woman, one man & no incumbent, women have been the top vote-getters in 71/109 cases (65%). On GOP side, 11/29 (38%).

This doesn't even include Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's upset in #NY14.
author: Redistrict

text:
That Dems didn't overperform '16 by much (if at all) in Saturday's #TX27 special isn't all that surprising. 

Which demographic group is most likely to drop off in off years vs. presidentials? Latinos (2nd only to 18-29). Who are Dems' base in Corpus Christi? Latinos.
author: Redistrict

text: Another aspect getting less attention than it should: vast majority of critical '18 races taking place in swingy/suburban districts. But safe seats like #NY14 are going to have an awful big say re: whom Dems nominate in '20.
author: Redistrict

text: Ironically, I think the #NY14 result says much more about the kind of profile that would excite the Dem base in '20 than it does about other '18 House primaries/races, where virtually all other incumbents will win.
author: Redistrict

text:
Besides, in convos w/ labor Dems in Howard Co., IA (only place that voted for Obama & Trump by 20%+, 98% white), barely heard about Russia/latest POTUS tweets/scandals. Top 3 refrains?

1) Get big $ out of politics
2) Medicare for all
3) Tax wealthy more
author: Redistrict

text:
Lots of warnings Dems risk falling off a socialist cliff. But let's say @Ocasio2018 were eligible to run in '20. Would Ds be better off w/ her or say...Biden? To me, not that close a call.

Outsider/insider & idgaf/canned now matter more to voters than ideology (see '16 result).
author: Redistrict

text: But that wouldn't be any fun...
author: Redistrict

text: IMHO, the viral & accelerated nature of today's politics means there's a real chance the 2020 Dem nominee will be someone virtually no one's talking about right now.
author: Redistrict

text:
After watching @Ocasio2018 become her party's biggest star overnight, it's plain to see what Dems desperately crave (need?) in '20: a young, charismatic woman w/ working-class street cred & a powerful story.

But here's their problem: who of constitutional age fits that bill?
author: Redistrict

text:
Meanwhile, so far in 2018 GOP primaries w/ at least one woman, one man & no incumbent on the ballot, women have won the most votes 8/21 times (38%).

BUT, GOP women did have a terrific night last night, winning 5/7 of these races, including in competitive #CA39, #CA49 & #NM02.
author: Redistrict

text: I've never seen anything quite like it: so far in 2018 Dem primaries w/ at least one woman, one man & no incumbent on the ballot, women have won the most votes 59/84 times (70%).
author: Redistrict

text: This is very helpful to get a sense of how much D/R %s can change between June and November in CA. Typically, Dems do better in Nov., particularly in outer burbs.
author: Redistrict

text: The only exception may be Valadao (R) in #CA21, who is currently 25% ahead of Cox (D). But even there, primary turnout was abysmal and Cox hasn’t had to start communicating because he didn’t have any top-two concerns.
author: Redistrict

text: Remember: the raging Bernie/Hillary contest inflated Dem %s in ‘16 CA primaries. Ordinarily, CA primaries skew quite R. Last night’s R % majorities in Dem target districts don’t really change my priors (and they’re far from final).
author: Redistrict

text: Keep in mind: not only is it too early to draw conclusions about party %s from primary (still lots to count), Nov. electorate will be more Dem than primary.

text:
Let me explain the #CA48 mystery. Right now, here are Orange Co.'s reported absentees by state Senate district for Keirstead/Baugh/Rouda:

#SD36: 2,296 / 1,929 / 1,527
#SD37: 5,024 / 4,971 / 4,553

But now take a look at:

#SD34: 5,065 / 4,964 / 2,007

That makes zero sense.
author: Redistrict

text: And that's not even taking into account a likely tabulation error that could be costing Rouda 2k votes.
author: Redistrict

text: It's Election Day vote, not a glitch fix.
author: Redistrict

text: To be clear, I found nonpartisan/compact maps would result in 3-4 additional D seats off the bat vs. current map. But they'd also add dozens more competitive districts, which would ease Dems' path to the majority in '18. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/redistricting-maps/#Compact …

text: We’re keeping #VA05 in Lean R at @CookPolitical pending a GOP replacement nominee. Keep in mind: this CD is a tad more R than it was when Tom Perriello eked out a massive upset in ‘08 wave.
author: Redistrict

text:
In '10/'14, GOP House primaries came to be defined by "job creators/outsiders" crushing legislators/politicians. It should've been a huge clue for '16.

In '18, Dem House primaries are coming to be defined by women trouncing men. Don't forget that when thinking about 2020.
author: Redistrict

text: Fact: primaries have been held in 147 districts - about 1/3 of the House. So far, women are 43% of all Dem nominees (and 51% of non-incumbents). Women are just 7% of all GOP nominees.
author: Redistrict

text: If '94 was the "year of the angry white male," '18 is on track to be the "year of the angry college-educated female." But the irony is...
author: Redistrict

text: Dec. '17 CNN/SSRS poll: 83% of Democrats said the country "would be governed better if more women were in political office," vs. 36% of Republicans. More than double the gap Gallup found on this Q in 2000. https://cdn.cnn.com/cnn/2017/images/12/21/rel12d.-.sexual.harassment.pdf …
author: Redistrict

text: Meanwhile, there's no comparable "gender bonus" on the GOP side. Had all Rs on the ballot received the same % (regardless of gender), women would've collectively averaged 28% across 14 mixed-gender GOP House primaries. In reality, they've averaged 30%.
author: Redistrict

text:
Had all Dems on the ballot received the same % (regardless of gender), women would've collectively averaged 39% across these 65 mixed-gender House primaries. In reality, they've averaged 54%. 

In other words, so far there's a "gender bonus" of ~15% for women in Dem primaries.
author: Redistrict

text: New story at @CookPolitical: Democrats' intense desire to elect women, not ideology, is defining the party's 2018 primaries. http://cookpolitical.com/analysis/house/house-overview/drive-elect-women-defining-2018s-democratic-primaries …
author: Redistrict

text: Fact: so far, there have been 14 GOP House primaries w/ at least one woman & one man (and no incumbent) on the ballot. Men have won 11, women just 3.
author: Redistrict

text: Fact: so far, there have been 65 Dem House primaries w/ at least one woman & one man (and no incumbent) on the ballot. Women have won 45 (and were the top vote-getters in 2 more heading to runoffs). Men: just 18.
author: Redistrict

text: Rather than "the details will all get worked out later" after a SCOTUS ruling vs. partisan gerrymandering, I want to hear more specifics from reformers on how clear & precise standards *could* be worked out.
author: Redistrict

text: Many proposed tests to detect partisan gerrymandering (such as Breyer's) sound great. But they're so vague that in practice, they could unleash a flood of claims without giving lower courts necessary guidance to navigate them.
author: Redistrict

text: Nonetheless, if SCOTUS does break new ground, this type of approach strikes me as a likelier outcome based on oral arguments than a math formula or something more drastic like mandatory independent commissions (which might produce better maps & save courts future hassle).
author: Redistrict

text: Recommended thread on principles (rather than mathematical formulas) SCOTUS could adopt to detect & outlaw partisan gerrymandering. However, "not easy" nor will "people will 100% agree" strike me as severe understatements.
author: Redistrict

text: Perhaps I should've said "bright line" rather than "explicit." If you believe it can be done with principles rather than formulas, I'd love to hear the specific principles/tests you see as judicially manageable.
author: Redistrict

text: I've yet to hear a clear articulation of how the Efficiency Gap could be uniformly applied to approve/reject a proposed map. What election data would be used? What's the threshold? What's gerrymandering vs. geography? But curious to hear your ideas for how SCOTUS should proceed.
author: Redistrict

text: Don't necessarily agree w/ this column's conclusion, but I've heard several well-intentioned reformers suggest that SCOTUS outlaw partisan gerrymandering w/o spelling out an explicit standard. That's a recipe for years of legal chaos at all levels.
author: Redistrict

text: The debate over partisan gerrymandering would be better served by less dwelling on its evils & more discussion about judicially manageable standards.
author: Redistrict

text: Actually, it's not. It's a consequence of the partisan distribution of voters.
author: Redistrict

text:
Here's the "proof" of mathematical impossibility, for those still confused by this riddle:

To draw 6/8 D+7 districts in WI, you'd need to draw two remaining districts that are R+21. There aren't enough R+21 precincts in WI to form two districts, even setting contiguity aside.
author: Redistrict

text: Nice try, but actually it would still be mathematically impossible, unless there were to be wide partisan variance within precincts that you could prove.
author: Redistrict

text: Fine, go ahead
author: Redistrict

text: The solution, then, might be to calculate the difference between the extreme map and the median simulated map, rather than distance from the statewide average.
author: Redistrict

text: If you can do it, I've still got $7,000.
author: Redistrict

text: Btw, I'm still willing to pay $7,000 for the map if you have verifiable election results at the sub-precinct level.
author: Redistrict

text: I don't disagree on that. "Possible" is not the same as "what would likely emerge from a partisan-blind process"
author: Redistrict

text: Within the bounds of what was possible, sure. But in PA, the median simulated map will always be to the right of the statewide average (which is not shown here).
author: Redistrict

text: I don't have a problem w/ anyone arguing for the maps they think are #FairMaps. But in most cases, the maps you want require mappers to actively compensate for an R geography advantage. And it's time to be honest about it.
author: Redistrict

text: Ward/precinct splitting doesn't even come close to explaining the partisan asymmetry of WI's political geography. What a strange hill to die on.
author: Redistrict

text: Twisting my "prediction" into evidence I declared the PA court "couldn't" adopt the plan you think is fair is called putting words in my mouth.
author: Redistrict

author: Redistrict

author: Redistrict

text: Ha. This is 100% untrue. I didn't care at all about compactness in this challenge. Go ahead, divide Madison & Milwaukee in as many directions as you want.
author: Redistrict

text: Not true
author: Redistrict

text: You're not alone. Even a few well-known academics in the redistricting field have a hard time wrapping their heads around such a thing as spatial partisan bias. But it exists. https://twitter.com/mattyglesias/status/979009887442173953 …
author: Redistrict

text: Nice work. Very close. If you ever find yourself in DC, I'll be happy to buy lunch - can't promise a $7,000 lunch, but the food will be good.

text: The irony: under your nonpartisan map, Rs would have had a great shot to win 6/8 seats in '16, which is more than the 5/8 they won under the actual R gerrymander.
author: Redistrict

text: Yup. D voters are more hyper-concentrated in cities/college towns than R voters (far more D+>25 precincts than R+>25 precincts). As a result, on balance, maps that prioritize compactness lead to more D wasted votes.
author: Redistrict

text:
For the last 7 years, I've argued that for Dems to win the House before 2022 (post-2021 redistricting), they would need either:

a) A resettlement program of their own voters
b) An unpopular GOP president in a midterm year

Guess what?
author: Redistrict

text: see above
author: Redistrict

text: The bottom line: Dems don't "deserve" to lose because they're inefficiently clustered in big cities/college towns/coastal America. But the fact that they are *does* moderately hurt their ability to win power in U.S. elections.
author: Redistrict

text: Is it possible to draw maps that create lots of competitive elections & treat parties symmetrically in these places? Of course it is. But in many places, you have to make conscious pro-Dem mapping choices (like breaking up cities) to compensate for a GOP geography advantage.
author: Redistrict

text: We could play out this exercise in dozens of states where the D vote is hyper-concentrated in cities/college towns (MI, PA, etc.). It's also why a *partisan-blind* cong. map, on balance, would slightly favor Rs:
author: Redistrict

text: Answer: It's easy to draw the GOP gerrymander, but the inverse Dem gerrymander isn't just hard - it's mathematically *impossible.* Despite WI's even partisanship, there is such a thing as a partisan bias in spatial distribution.
author: Redistrict

text: By our estimates, Dems need to win ~7% more House votes than Republicans to win an equal number of seats this November. But gerrymandering's not the sole culprit. Voter geography, incumbency & uncontested races are big factors too.
author: Redistrict

text: Where I take exception is when people talk about gerrymandering as if it's the exclusive reason Dems need to win ~7% more votes than Rs to win an equal number of seats. Geography, incumbency & uncontested races are big factors too.

To participate, visit http://davesredistricting.org , and use v. 2.2, which allows you to calculate PVI in real time as you draw. Rules:

2) All 8 districts must be within 1,000 residents of the ideal population (710,873)

author: Redistrict

text: If you don't care about compactness, you can. That's fine. But one of the main arguments against GOP's PA gerrymander was that it wasn't remotely compact.
author: Redistrict

text: Maybe this illustration will help: WI was basically tied in 2016. It's really easy to draw a compact 6-2 Trump CD map by packing Dems in Madison & Milwaukee. Now try to draw a similarly compact 6-2 Clinton map. You can't.

text:
In the last midterms (2014), Rs won 5.7% more votes for House than Ds and 13.6% more seats, a difference of 7.9%.

In '18, maps are less favorable to Rs in FL/PA/VA than in '14. Even a Dem vote advantage of 6-7% could flip House, though 7-8% is a better bet.
author: Redistrict

text: That is also...very incorrect. If Dems win the House popular vote by 10% and fail to take back the House, I'll buy lunch for you & the entire @BrennanCenter.
author: Redistrict

text: I'd estimate 7-8%
author: Redistrict

text: BTW, Dems have strong '18 pickup opportunities on most of these "extreme" maps. These R maps were drawn in 2011. Now, they're beginning to unravel b/c a) suburbs have trended away from Rs and b) anti-Trump midterm wave.
author: Redistrict

text: It's possible to make the case other states are "mild" GOP gerrymanders. But there are also a few states w/ Dem gerrymanders: IL, MA, MD. The takeaway: GOP gerrymandering is clearly an obstacle to Dems retaking the House, but not as huge of one as commonly thought.
author: Redistrict

text: Here's an exercise: what % of 2018 House elections will be held in states w/ "extreme" GOP gerrymanders still in place? I bet it's smaller than a lot of people think. If you add up GA, MI, MO, NC, OH, TX, UT, WI - that's still only about 26% of all 435 House seats.
author: Redistrict

text: No. Dems' problem is that they're winning a few urban districts by 60%-70% and losing many more suburban seats by smaller margins. This could change in an '18 wave.
author: Redistrict

text: Lastly, I'm well aware we've debated this a million times & I'll be criticized/ratio'd for arguing gerrymandering's effects are overstated. But, I'd propose a friendly wager to @mcpli & @lauraroyden: if Dems' seat/vote margins are >10% apart, I'll buy lunch & vice versa. Deal?
author: Redistrict

text: 3) In the past 3 elections, Dems have won ~4% fewer seats than votes. We estimate Dems would need to win House popular vote by ~7% to win barest possible majority. If Dems win the popular vote by 11%, they'll be well on their way to a clear majority.
author: Redistrict

text: 2) It isn't so much "technology and data-fueled 21st century gerrymandering" that's enhanced the effectiveness of partisan maps. It's the heightened geographic polarization of the American electorate, which has made it easier for parties to draw "safe" seats.
author: Redistrict

text: 1) It's always misleading to cite "extreme gerrymandering" as an obstacle to Dems retaking House without citing the extreme urbanization of the Democratic vote that's led to millions more wasted votes. These two phenomena coexist & are both important drivers of the GOP advantage.
author: Redistrict

text: At the moment, there are all kinds of fancy models flying around projecting out the relationship b/t national polls and the House seat count. That's all well and good. But there are limitations to data. Candidates & campaigns are going to matter.

text:
The only path left for GOP to keep its House majority involves some combo of these two things:

a) Generic ballot deficit ends up at something more manageable than double digits (say, 6-7%).
b) GOP succeeds in individually turning Dem candidates into unacceptable alternatives.
author: Redistrict

text: So are parts of VA. But we didn't see Dems massively overperform in HoD races in the far southwest of VA, for example.
author: Redistrict

text: True of congressional specials, of which we don't have a very large data set. Also true that the most staggering Dem overperformances vs. '16 have come in extreme low-turnout state leg. specials (KY, MO, OK, etc.) and weren't matched in high turnout VA HoD races.
author: Redistrict

text:
Taken together, off-year results suggest:

a) Dems enjoy an intensity gap that looks like '10/'14 in reverse
b) Dems are regaining ground in places Trump surged in '16 while Rs are regaining none of their old strength in the suburbs.
c) Dems are modest favorites for the House.
author: Redistrict

text: But congressional specials have been powerful indicators too: they've been federal, high $$ fights w/ generally awful results for the GOP. To me, they're most useful in highlighting how much Rs could struggle to hold onto their own open House seats this fall.
author: Redistrict

text:
IMHO, the most telling off-year results for 11/18 purposes have been VA's HoD races, which featured:

a) GOP incumbents (unlike specials)
b) Gov turnout (similar to midterms)
c) Big Dem gains (could've won majority had Dems funded more "2nd tier" races where they fell just short)
author: Redistrict

text:
I'm with you on the 2nd pt. It's foolish to extrapolate extremely low-turnout state leg specials to cong midterms.

On #PA18, Lamb was as superior to Saccone as you can be while staying within the realm of "normal" candidates. Dems aren't going to get that biography everywhere.
author: Redistrict

text: I'm not so sure. #PA18 and #ALSEN featured some of the widest/rarest Dem advantages in candidate quality among high-turnout races. If you factor in state leg specials, the most staggering Dem overperformances (Long Island, KY, MO, OK) have come amid extremely low turnout.
author: Redistrict
