text: That's exactly the problem. Because there's no clear SCOTUS standard, the decisions to bring suits vs. over-packing of minority voters are driven largely by partisan considerations, not protection of minority voters.
author: Redistrict

text: I'd like to know how the racial intent in VA and NC was provable in a way the intent in AL and LA isn't. My point is that under the current VRA regime, equal protection for minorities across state lines is lacking. Same could be true for partisan minorities.
author: Redistrict

text: Then why haven't #LA02 and #AL07 been struck down the way #VA03 and #NC12 have been? They clearly overpack African-Americans in a similar way.
author: Redistrict

text: I'm skeptical of an "it'll all get worked out later" approach. I doubt appellate courts of varying/evolving ideologies will settle on a lasting standard for partisan harm. Just look at race: what's considered unconstitutional packing in VA/NC still stands in AL/LA.
author: Redistrict

text: If the court articulates the harm we should be looking for without adopting a measurable standard to outlaw it, wouldn't there be a risk of lower courts adopting their own varying standards and gerrymanders being struck down incongruously?
author: Redistrict

text: That's a fair place to start. But in your opinion, which elections should be used to calculate the efficiency gap/partisan bias? What threshold do you favor for how much bias is too much? How should judges assess what % of bias is attributable to mapping choices vs. geography?
author: Redistrict

text: I'm open to the possibility there's a workable anti-gerrymandering standard for SCOTUS to adopt. I also believe those who argue it's destroying democracy should be prepared to advocate for specific proposals to fix the problem & make maps fair.
author: Redistrict

text: Agree with much (not all) of this piece, but most curious about Myth #5: @AriBerman, what do you see as a manageable test for the SCOTUS to identify/outlaw gerrymandering? Looking for specifics.

text: The most accurate way to think about partisan impact of new PA map isn't "Dems gain x seats from it." It's that the new map replaced 6 existing Dem pickup opportunities w/ 6 *much stronger* opportunities: (#PA01, #PA05, #PA06, #PA07, #PA10, #PA17).
author: Redistrict

text: Fact: PA's political geography naturally advantages GOP. It's tough to draw 9/18 districts to elect Dems without splitting Philadelphia/Pittsburgh many ways. Just the way it is - sorry you don't get this concept.
author: Redistrict

text: The "very definition of our democracy?" No, that's called proportional representation. If you favor that, fine. Our single-member district system is ill-equipped to guarantee PR. Example: Dems won ~1/3 of the vote in WV - but it's impossible to draw a Clinton district there.
author: Redistrict

text: Terrific explainer of why the new PA lines are even better for Dems than expected. Dems' pickup opportunities in ~5 seats just got a lot better.
author: Redistrict

text: P.S. Dems' natural geographic disadvantage has *zero* to do w/ land mass/density. It has to do with concentration of their voters in Philadelphia/Pittsburgh - made it difficult to spread Dems across many PA districts without violating the court's compactness criteria.
author: Redistrict

text: Examples: new PA map splits Berks Co. (Reading) in a way that gives Dems an advantage in #PA06. Splits York Co. in a way that helps Dems in #PA10. Splits Luzerne Co. in a way that protects Rep. Matt Cartwright (D) in #PA08.
author: Redistrict

text: Make no mistake: this is the PA map Dems wanted. It's a ringing endorsement of the "partisan fairness" doctrine: that parties should be entitled to same proportion of seats as votes. However, in PA (and many states), achieving that requires conscious pro-Dem mapping choices.
author: Redistrict

text: Holder statement on new PA map: “The fair map issued by the state Supreme Court is a major victory in the fight against gerrymandering in Pennsylvania and around the country...Republicans all over the country should be on notice - their days of partisan map-rigging are numbered."
author: Redistrict

text: A caveat for Dems: two Lancaster Dems, Christina Hartman & Jess King, have raised $300k+ for #PA16. Now that $$ is pretty useless & Dems need a Harrisburg candidate against Rep. Scott Perry (R) in new #PA10 instead.
author: Redistrict

text: The result: Dems have a great shot to win 8-11 of PA's 18 seats in November. Under a truly partisan-blind compact map, maybe 7-10. Under old GOP map, maybe 6-9.
author: Redistrict

text: Bottom line: the PA Supreme Court's map doesn't just undo the GOP's gerrymander. It goes further, actively helping Dems compensate for their natural geographic disadvantage in PA.
author: Redistrict

text:
Lots of people think there's some fancy new computer models/secret sauce that's made gerrymandering more insidious. Not really: the tech's been around for decades. 

The reality: gerrymandering's become more effective in recent years because the U.S. electorate is more polarized.

text: Would Minimum Split Districting eradicate partisan gerrymandering? Of course not. But would it outlaw the most egregious cases? Absolutely.
author: Redistrict

text: MSD could boost minority voting strength in long-term. Current glut of packed, gerrymandered CDs hurts minority representation overall.
author: Redistrict

text: It might actually look a lot like the 2016 plan. Still pro-GOP, but maybe 4th CD entirely within Wake & more compact/competitive.
author: Redistrict

text: If you can create a compact minority-majority seat adhering to these rules, it must be drawn. If not, too bad: gerrymandering not allowed.
author: Redistrict

text: Moreover, if subdivisions are large enough, full CDs must be drawn within. For example, Wake/Mecklenburg get their own, no ifs/ands/buts.
author: Redistrict

text: MSD would require states to adhere to the absolute minimum # of county/city/precinct splits needed to create equally populous districts.
author: Redistrict

text: But here's an idea for a bright line, SCOTUS: mandate "Minimum Split Districting" to curtail most egregious racial/partisan gerrymandering.
